choices.text: Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) stimulates the collagen degradation by increasing matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) activity and decreasing the activity of tissue inhibitors of proteinases (TIMPs)
The degradation of collagens and other ECM components is accomplished by a family of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP)
Benign tumours of the stomach and breast have high matrix metalloproteinases (MMP-9) activity, whereas their malignant counterparts don't express this enzyme
Decreased MMP production, especially by macrophages, can contribute to aneurysm development

questions.text: Which one of the following is true regarding matrix metalloproteinase s (MMPs)?
questions.solution:
A) GF-β stimulates the production of collagen, fibronectin, and proteoglycans and inhibits collagen degradation by both decreasing matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) activity and increasing the activity of tissue inhibitors of proteinases (TIMPs).

B) MMPs regulate tumour invasion not only by remodelling the basement membrane( collagen degradation) and interstitial connective tissue, but also by releasing factors that contribute to the malignant behaviour of cancers.

C) Benign tumours of the breast, colon, and stomach have little MMP-9 activity, whereas their malignant counterparts overexpress this enzyme

D) Inflammatory cells in the setting of an aortitis or associated with atherosclerosis can be found throughout the aortic wall. Increased MMP production, especially by macrophages, can contribute to aneurysm development by degrading ECM (elastin, collagens, proteoglycans, laminin, fibronectin) in all layers of the wall; decreased expression of TIMPs can also impact ECM degradation.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 3,7 & 11 page number. 308, 505.

questions.text: Identify the pigment deposition (black arrow) in between cardiac myocytes in following microphotograph.
questions.solution:
Lipofuscin (wear & tear pigment)

  • an insoluble pigment,
  • also known as lipochrome or wear-and-tear pigment.
  • Lipofuscin is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids in complex with protein, suggesting that it is derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membranes.
  • Its importance lies in its being a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • The term is derived from the Latin (fuscus, brown), referring to brown lipid.
  • In tissue sections, it appears as a yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic, often perinuclear, pigment.
  • It is seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes and is particularly prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 2, pg no.64, 65.

Textbook of Pathology, Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 1, chapter 2, pagenumber. 22.

questions.text: Which are the most common sites of metastases from renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - its tendency to metastasize widely before giving rise to any local symptoms or signs. In 15% of new patients with renal cell carcinoma, there is radiologic evidence of metastases at the time of presentation.
  • The most common locations of metastasis are: Lungs (more than 50%) > bones (33%) > regional lymph nodes > liver > adrenal glands > brain.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 20, page number. 951.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines are associated in chronic inflammation?
questions.solution: Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 3, page number.89.

choices.text: It has mitogenic effect on platelets, T lymphocytes, macrophages, endothelial cells, epithelial cells
It stimulates extracellular protein matrix (ECM) protein synthesis

questions.text: About Transforming growth factor (TGF - Beta), which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution: Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 1, page number.20.

choices.text: Location and vascular drainage of the primary tumor
Tropism of particular kinds of tumor cells for specific tissues
Duration and extent of the tumor

questions.text: Which factor from the following do not relate with metastatic deposits from arrested circulating tumor cells that do not relate from the following factors?
questions.solution:
• Where circulating tumor cells arrest and eventually form clinically significant metastatic deposits appears to relate to three factors:
    1. Location and vascular drainage of the primary tumor;
    2. Tropism of particular kinds of tumor cells for specific tissues; and
    3. Escape from tumor dormancy.
  • Even when metastatic cells take root and survive within Distant tissues, they may fail to grow. This phenomenon, called tumor dormancy.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 7, page number. 308, 309.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause cresentic glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Cresentic glomerulonephritis


  • It is characterized by relatively rapid and progressive loss of renal function associated with severe oliguria and signs of nephritic syndrome; if untreated, death from renal failure may occur within weeks to months.
  • The most common histologic picture is the presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli, hence the name crescentic glomerulonephritis.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 20, page number. 909.

questions.text: Shock lung is characterized by
questions.solution:
• The cellular and tissue effects of shock are essentially those of hypoxic injury and are caused by a combination of hypoperfusion and microvascular thrombosis.
  • Whereas the lungs are resistant to hypoxic injury in hypovolemic shock occurring after hemorrhage, sepsis or trauma can precipitate diffuse alveolar damage, leading to so-called "shock lung."

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 4, page number. 138.

choices.text: Pancreatic abnormalities are less likely in the patients of the cystic fibrosis
Secondary obstruction and infection of the air passages

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding cystic fibrosis, except:
questions.solution:
• Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder of ion transport that affects fluid secretion in exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and reproductive organs.
  • CFTR gene mutation (option C)
  • Pancreatic abnormalities are present in approximately 85% to 90% of patients with cystic fibrosis (option a)
  • Liver - Hepatic steatosis, focal biliary cirrhosis (in approximately one-third of patients)
  • Lung - the viscous mucus secretions of the submucosal glands of the respiratory tree, leading to secondary obstruction and infection of the air passages.(option D)
  • Azoospermia (option B) and infertility are found in 95% of males Who survive to adulthood; congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens is a frequent finding in these patients

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 4, page number 466-473.

questions.text: Which of the following is an electron microscopic finding in biopsy of mesothelioma of pleura?
questions.solution:
• Electron microscopy played a pivotal role in the differential diagnosis between mesothelioma and metastatic carcinoma, to the point of being considered the gold standard.
  • It is primarily based on the appearance of the microvilli in the apical surface of the tumor cells, which in mesothelioma are longer and more slender than those in adenocarcinoma which can be appreciated in the following picture.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 11, page number 418

questions.text:
A 38 years old man presents with weakness and wasting of the muscles of his left hand for 10 months. Patient is having fasciculations of that hand, impaired speech and later on he dies of respiratory problems after 3 years. Autopsy findings were consistent with ventral roots atrophy in the spinal cord.


What possible diagnosis can be made from above clinopathological details?
questions.solution:
• ALS is a progressive disorder in which there is loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
  • The disease affects motor neurons in 3 locations:
    • The anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
    • The motor nuclei of the brain stem, particularly hypoglassal nuclei
    • The upper motor neurons of the cerebral cortex.
  • Loss of these neurons results in denervation of muscles, producing weakness that becomes profound as the disease progresses.
  • It starts with weakness and wasting of the muscles of the hand, often accompanied by painful cramps of the muscles of the arm.
  • Here the microscopic image of Spinal cord showing loss of myelinated fibers (lack of stain) in corticospinal tracts (best seen on the right side of this specimen; arrow) as well as degeneration of anterior roots (arrowhead).
  • The other 3 choices do not affect motor neurons of the spinal cord.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter - 28. Page number 1287, 1288.

choices.text: Grossly it shows hemorrhagic and cystic areas
It arises from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions

questions.text:
A 65 years old man presents to General Surgery Outpatient with complaints of fever, malaise, weakness and gross painless haematuria and pain in left flank. There is also history of loss of 6 kg weight in the last 3 months. A left-sided flank mass is palpable on bimanual examination. The microscopic image of the mass is shown below.


Which one of the following is false?
questions.solution:
• Microscopic image favours Papillary renal carcinoma.
  • Other types of RCCs are clear cell carcinoma( most common), chromophobe carcinoma, collecting duct carcinoma.
  • Clear cell carcinomas most likely arise from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions.
  • Papillary carcinomas, thought to arise from distal convoluted tubules, can be multifocal and bilateral (D) They are typically hemorrhagic and cystic, especially when large (c) . The tumor is composed of cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formations. Interstitial foam cells are common in the papillary cores. Psammoma bodies may be present (B).
  • The classic clinical features of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and hematuria.
  • Papillary carcinoma is characterized by a papillary growth pattern and also occurs in both familial and sporadic forms. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities are trisomies 7 (A) and 17 and loss of Y in male patients in the sporadic form, and trisomy 7 in the familial form.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 20, page number 950.

questions.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord is caused by which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord is caused by deficiency of vitamin B12 and is marked by degeneration of the ascending and descending spinal tracts. The lesions result from a defect in myelin formation.
  • Hypoglycemia- Glucose deprivation initially leads to selective injury to large cortical pyramidal neurons, which, if severe, may result in pseudolaminar necrosis of the cortex, predominantly involving deep layers.
  • Thiamine deficiency (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome) - consists of two related manifestations.
    • Wernicke encephalopathy is characterized by acute psychosis and ophthalmology.
    • These symptoms are reversible when treated with thiamine. However, if unrecognized and untreated, they may be followed by a prolonged and largely irreversible condition (Korsakoff syndrome) that is marked by disturbances of short-term memory and confabulation. The syndrome is particularly common in the setting of chronic alcoholism.
    • In Wernicke encephalopathy, there are foci of hemorrhage and necrosis in the mamillary bodies and the walls of the third and fourth ventricles.
    • Early lesions show dilated capillaries with prominent endothelial cells; subsequently, the capillaries become leaky, producing hemorrhagic areas. With time, there is infiltration of macrophages and development of a cystic space containing hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter –28. Page number 1291,1292.

choices.text: These tumors located peripherally near the pleura are less common than central tumors
Unlike other lung tumors, it is not immunoreactive for TTF-1

questions.text: Which of the following statements about this lung malignancy (microscopic image) is true?
questions.solution:
• Gross examination - the central tumors grow as finger-like or spherical polypoid masses that commonly project into the lumen of the bronchus. Most are confined to the mainstem bronchi. Small cell carcinoma is typically a lesion of the central portions of the lung, only occasionally it is found in a peripheral location. (Option C)
  • Microscopically - the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. The tumor cells have uniform round nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. (figure)
  • Electron microscopy the cells exhibit the dense-core granules. (Option B)
  • Immunohistochemistry - positive for keratins, TTF-1, serotonin, neuronspecific enolase(NSE), bombesin, calcitonin, Synaptophysin, chromogranin, CD56. (Option d)

Reference:

Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 15, page number 783, 794, 801, 809.

Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 10, page number. 407-408.

questions.text: A 34 years-old-female's clinical presentation, including weight loss, skin pigmentation, glossitis, joint pain, angular cheilitis, lymphadenopathy, and steatorrhea. Blood culture are negative. The patient is started on antibiotic therapy and exhibites remarkable improvement. The biopsy findings are distorted intestinal villi and a periodic acid-Schiff stain revealed foamy macrophages with glycoprotein-rich granuless (as shown in the image). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Whipple disease

  • Whipple disease is an infectious disorder of the small intestine in which malabsorption is the most prominent feature.
  • The disorder typically features infiltration of the small bowel mucosa by macrophages that are packed with small, rod-shaped bacilli (Tropheryma whippelit). (A)
  • Infiltrates of macrophages containing bacilli may be found in other organs, including regional lymph nodes and the heart.
  • The other choices do not feature these distinctive aggregates of foamy macrophages.
  • Angiodysplastic lesions are characterized By ectatic nests of tortuous veins, venules, and capillaries.(C)
  • Peutz-Jeghers polyp exhibits the treelike branching of muscularis mucosae. The lining epithelium is by normal-appearing epithelial cells. The glands may show hyperplasia and cystic change.
  • Crohn's disease- (B)
    1. Typically transmural Inflammation
    2. Non-caseating granulomas and infiltrate of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophages)
    3. Fibrosis

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, page number 783, 794, 801, 809.

questions.text: 3 years before the onset of recurrent dysuria, a patient had a rupture of the bladder, which was surgically repaired. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the following figures?
questions.solution:
Nephrogenic adenoma

Some inflammatory or metaplastic bladder lesions which clinically and/or histologically mimic bladder cancer. These are

  • Malakoplakia
  • Polypoid cystitis
  • Cystitis cystica et glandularis
  • Nephrogenic adenoma.
  • Nephrogenic adenoma
    • Not a true form of metaplasia.
    • The lesions are typically less than 1 cm in size
    • Urothelium is focally replaced by cuboidal epithelium
    • Delicate papillations of the surface with associated tubules and microcysts in the adjacent stroma
    • Hobnail appearance can be seen
    • In addition, the tubular proliferation can infiltrate the underlying lamina propria and superficial detrusor muscle, microscopically mimicking a malignant process.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 21, page number 957.

questions.text: A 56 years old mason complains of chronic nonproductive cough, fatigue, loss of appetite and chest pain along with dyspnea, becoming progressive since last few months. A chest xray suggested small nodular shadows and calcifications in the peripheral lymph nodes of upper lobes. He gave a history of 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking. The pulmonary function test result and microscopic image from the biopsy is shown below.
questions.solution:
• Silicosis is a common lung disease caused by inhalation of proinflammatory crystalline silicon dioxide (silica).
  • Grossly in its early stages by tiny, barely palpable, discrete pale to blackened nodules in the hilar lymph nodes and upper zones of the lungs. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into hard, collagenous scars. Some nodules may undergo central softening and cavitation due to superimposed tuberculosis or to ischemia.
  • Fibrotic lesions may also occur in the hilar lymph nodes and pleura. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification occur in the lymph nodes and are seen radiographically as eggshell calcification (i.e., calcium surrounding a zone lacking calcification).
  • If the disease continues to progress, expansion and coalescence of lesions may produce progressive massive fibrosis.
  • Histologic examination reveals the hallmark lesion characterized by a central area of whorled collagen fibers with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophage
  • Polarized microscopy reveals weakly birefringent silicate particles.
  • Results of PFTs are useful for categorizing a lung disease as either obstructive or restrictive.
  • PULMONARY FUNCTION TESTS (PFT)
    • In individuals with diffuse obstructive disorders, PFT show decreased maximal airflow rates during forced expiration, usually expressed as forced expiratory volume at 1 second (FEV1) over forced ventilatory capacity (FVC).
    • An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 generally indicates obstructive disease.
    • By contrast, restrictive diseases are associated with proportionate decreases in both total lung capacity and FEV1 , such that the FEV1/FVC ratio remains normal.
    • Restrictive defects occur in two broad kinds of conditions:
      1. chest wall disorders (e.g., severe obesity, pleural diseases, kyphoscoliosis, and neuromuscular diseases such as poliomyelitis) and
      2. chronic interstitial and infiltrative diseases, such as pneumoconioses and interstitial fibrosis.
  • Given that the patient's PFT result indicates a restrictive lung disease, hence COPD (Option C) can be ruled out. Asbestosis( option A) and silicosis (option B) are restrictive lung diseases, however, the patient's chest x-ray shows egg-shell calcification in the peripheral lymph nodes of the upper lobes, a classic finding in patients with
  • Sarcoidosis shows non caseating granuloma (option D)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 15, page number 693, 694, 678, 697.

choices.text: The inflammatory cells are most commonly lymphocytes and plasma cells
The organism is concentrated within the superficial mucus overlying epithelial cells in the surface and neck regions
The antrum is the preferred biopsy site for evaluation of H. pylori gastritis
Chronic H. pylori gastritis is associated with increased risk of both gastric adenocarcinoma and lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding H. Pylori associated gastritis?
questions.solution:
• Gastric biopsy specimens generally demonstrate H. pylori in infected individuals.
  • The organism is concentrated within the superficial mucus overlying epithelial cells in the surface and neck regions. (Option b)
  • The distribution can be irregular, with areas of heavy colonization adjacent to those with few organisms.
  • The antrum is the preferred biopsy site for evaluation of H.pylori gastritis because it is most commonly infected. (Option c)
  • Lymphoid aggregates, some with germinal centers, are frequently present and represent induced mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) that has the potential to transform into lymphoma. Thus, chronic H. pylori gastritis is associated with increased risk of both gastric adenocarcinoma and lymphoma. (Option D)
  • Neutrophils infiltrate across the basement membrane and accumulate in the lumens of gastric glands, or pits, to create pit abscesses. (Option A)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, page number 767, 768.

questions.text: 52 years old man with a past history of a renal transplant presented with a history of dementia, weakness and visual loss. According to the brain biopsy microscopic picture, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an opportunistic demyelinating disease caused by DNA viruses of the polyoma group.

Nearly all clinical isolates responsible for the disorder have been strains of the ubiquitous JC virus.

PML is almost always associated with defective cell-mediated immunity.

The disease is characterized by subacutely evolving multifocal neurologic symptoms, chiefly motor deficits, cognitive decline, and visual loss.

Infection of these cells results in progressive nuclear enlargement with plum-colored viral inclusions within oligodendrocytes and result in enlarged cells with marginated chromatin.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 43, page number. 1973, 1974.

choices.text: It is more common in females than in males
RET oncogene activating mutations are found in about 70% of familial HD cases
Leads to proximally constricted and distally dilated aganglionic segment
Overexpression of parasympathetic ganglion cells in the intramural and submucosal plexuses

questions.text: Which of the following about Hirschsprung disease (HD) is true?
questions.solution:
• Hirschsprung disease occurs in 1 in 5,000 to 30,000 liver births
  • M>F
  • Absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) and the presence of hypertrophic nerves in both submucosal and myenteric plexus.
  • Total colonic aganglionosis occur in 5% of cases.
  • Leads to poor peristalsis and obstruction - Proximal dilatation with narrowed, spastic and distal aganglionic segment.
  • Failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, constipation- can get enterocolitis.
  • Rectal suction biopsies can demonstrate the submucosal plexus and are commonly performed to document the presence of aganglionosis. (2 CM above dentate line)
  • Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene and the EDNRB gene can lead to HD.
  • Point mutations in RET gene can cause
    1. HD,
    2. Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia-II (MEN-II) and
    3. Familial Medullary Thyroid carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, page number 755.

choices.text: GISTs show particular type and location of mutations in c-KIT which has diagnostic and therapeutic value
Recurrence or metastasis is rare for gastric GISTs smaller than 5 cm but common for mitotically active tumors larger than 10 cm
c) The most common sites of metastases of malignant GISTs are the thyroid and bone
Multiple GIST are associated with neurofibromatosis 1 and carney triad

questions.text: All the following statement are correct of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen.
  • The most common sites of metastases of malignant GISTs are the liver, peritoneum and lungs. (Option C)
  • GISTs may present in the form of multiple tumors in the following situations:
    1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease) (option d)
    2. Carney triad
    3. Associated with paraganglioma but different from Carney triad (Carney-Stratakis syndrome)
    4. As a familial syndrome, associated with germline mutations of KIT and with small intestinal neuronal dysplasia.
  • Recurrence or metastasis is rare for gastric GISTs smaller than 5 cm but common for mitotically active tumors larger than 10 cm. (Option b)
  • Approximately 75% of all GISTs have oncogenic, gain of function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT. Another 8% of GISTs have mutations that activate the related receptor tyrosine kinase, platelet-derived growth factor receptor α (PDGFRA) (option A).

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, page number 778, 779.

questions.text: Which of the following predisposing lesions lead to the development of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Gastric carcinoma does not arise de novo from a normal mucosa. Chronic atrophic gastritis and intestinal metaplasia commonly precede and or accompany adenocarcinoma of intestinal type in gastric region. (Option B)
  • Other predisposing factors are -
    • Pylori associated gastritis,
    • Gastric ulcer,
    • Hyperplastic polyps and
    • Gastric adenoma. (Option A)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, page number 767, 774.

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis - associated interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD)

questions.text: Masson bodies are characteristically found in which of the following types of interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is most often seen as a response to infection or inflammatory injury of the lungs.

It has been associated with viral and bacterial pneumonias, inhaled toxins, drugs, connective tissue disease, and graftversus-host disease in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients.

Clinical symptoms -cough and dyspnea

Radiograxphy findings - patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of airspace consolidation.

Histologically - the presence of polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue (Masson bodies) within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles (Fig). The connective tissue is all of the same age, and the underlying lung architecture is normal. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycomb lung.

Some patients recover spontaneously, but most need treatment with oral steroids for 6 months or Longer for complete recovery. The long-term prognosis is dependent on the underlying disorder.

Above 2 microscopic images show Some alveolar spaces are filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies), while the alveolar walls are relatively normal. (A) Low power. (B) High power.



Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 15, page number 690, 691.

choices.text: Desmoplastic small round blue cell tumor

questions.text: Loss of WTl gene function may occur in any of the following conditions EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Loss of WT1 gene function characteristically occurs in

(Mnemonic – Do Not Discuss World War in a Meeting)

  • Denys-Drash syndrome
  • Nephrogenic rests
  • Desmoplastic small round cell tumor
  • Wilms tumor,
  • WAGR syndrome
  • Mesoblastic nephroma

but not in cystic nephroma.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 24, page number. 1015.

choices.text: i - A, ii - B, iii - D, iv - E, v - C
i - E, ii - B, iii - D, iv - A, v - C
i - A, ii - C, iii - B, iv - E, v - D
i - B, ii - E, iii - C, iv - A, v - D

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV) :-

  • The histologic appearance is similar to anaplastic astrocytoma with the additional features of necrosis and/or microvascular proliferation.
  • Necrosis in glioblastoma often occurs in a serpentine pattern with tumor hypercellularity along the edges of the necrotic regions, a histologic pattern referred to as palisading.

Pilocytic Astrocytoma (WHO grade I) :-

  • Biphasic architecture combining loose "microcystic" and compact, densely fibrillar areas (Fig. 28.49B). The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin "hairlike' processes that are GFAPpositive and form a dense fibrillary meshwork; Rosenthal fibers (eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions) and eosinophilic granular bodies (mulberry-like inclusions) are characteristic findings.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) :-

  • Autosomal dominant syndrome
  • Characterized by the development of hamartomas and benign neoplasms involving the brain and other tissues
  • The most frequent clinical manifestations are seizures, autism, and intellectual disability.
  • Cortical hamartomas of TSC are firm areas that, in contrast to the softer adjacent cortex, have been likened to potatoes (hence the appellation "tubers").
  • The tubers are composed of haphazardly arranged neurons that lack the normal laminar organization.
  • Similar hamartomatous features are present in the subependymal nodules, where the large astrocyte-like cells cluster beneath the ventricular surface. These small waxlike masses that bulge into the ventricular system gave rise to the term candle-gutterings.

Medulloblastoma :-

  • Densely cellular tumor , with sheets of small primitive appearing cells.
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped.
  • Mitoses are abundant, and markers of cellular proliferation, such as Ki-67, are positive in a high percentage of the cells.
  • In the classic subtype, tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes (two black arrows)

Oligodendroglioma :-

  • Oligodendrogliomas are gelatinous, gray masses, often with cysts, focal hemorrhage, and calcification.
  • The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm (Fig. 28.48).
  • The tumor typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling "chicken wire."

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 28, page number 1294-1302.
